course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Deep Learning for Natural Language Processing
course.description: This course covers the basic theories and applications of natural language processing including speech processing using deep learning. It also introduces the topic of ethics in Artificial Intelligence. Topics include distributional semantics with word embeddings, text classification, emotion recognition, sentiment analysis from text and speech, language modeling, machine translation, and question answering. We will also cover multi-linguality and multi-modality, end-to-end chatbots, and task-oriented dialogue systems. The topics in Deep Learning ranges from feed forward neural networks, convolutional neural networks, recurrent neural networks, sequence-to-sequence neural networks, and the latest architecture in DL. Students will learn about various natural language processing (NLP) topics, how to design and build a deep learning model using PyTorch and Python, and the basics of software engineering. At the end of the course, students will work alone or in pairs to implement a deep learning model for various NLP research tasks, and describe their methods and results in a conference paper format. Successful groups will be able to submit their papers to an international conference.
course.prerequisites: (COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H) AND (ELEC 2600 OR ELEC 2600H)

reviews.author: Zori
reviews.title: High workload, Ordinary teaching, Good grade
reviews.comment_content:
This course is very suitable for people who look forward to learning more about the neural network (NN in abbreviation) if they only have a sense of it in the very beginning and the ones who are interested in natural language processing as a beginner.
Covering the general topics in natural language processing (NLP in abbreviation). The content is thoroughly explained in the course description. So there are basically three dimensions in the course content: NLP functions, NN architecture, and code implementation.
For the NLP functions, it basically demonstrates the various functions achieved by current NLP tech, such as emotion detection and so on.
For the NN architecture, it introduces the basic structure of NN, CNN, RNN, Seq to Seq, and transformer. Meanwhile, it also introduces the word2vec, word embedding concepts, which are critical in NLP.
For the code implementation, you need to construct a complete model structure to fulfill a specific task in every homework, such as sentiment classification and so on.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ordinary.
The Prof would elaborate on the content she teaches based on the notes. But the teaching is prone to academic and not that attractive.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very good.
It is a course with mixed UG and PG students.
The grading scheme:
Attendance - 10%
Homework - 40% ( 4 x 10%)
Midterm - 25%
Report - 25% ( You would first need to form up a 2-people team. Then, you need to select a topic related to NLP. The prof would provide alternatives for you, but you may feel free to select others that interest you. My team selects a topic relating to fake news detection)
The last two homework and report grading is not released. I got about 1 sd above mean in midterm and the first two homework, ending in A+. The prof said the grading can be good given that it is a small class.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty heavy.
Spending about 6-10 hours for one piece of homework every two weeks.
The midterm also requires review.
The report involves research and a lot of model tuning.
